item.name: 51st State
item.comment: Ok game, but looking up all those different icons kills it for me.

item.name: Age of Empires III: The Age of Discovery
item.comment: Good game, just didn't grab me.

item.name: Agricola
item.comment: So far this is a good game. Not really my choice of theme but the mechanics are good. It suffers a little bit from AP due to overwhelming number of choices compared to possible actions.

item.name: Akrotiri
item.comment: I don't usually enjoy pick-up and delivery games but this one is really good.

item.name: Alien Uprising
item.comment:
The rulebook is atrocious. Everything is scattered all over the place and basic concepts are presented in a confusing manner and/or poorly explained, leaving the player to guess/assume how to play the game. Not impressed.
The game itself has interesting setting and premise but would be ten times more fun if it was streamlined and had a more intuitive flow. There is too much to check back and forth to make sure you're doing things right, hence I found it not possible to play without constantly referencing the rulebook...which is a mess to begin with. Not fun.
Shame, the main drive of the game is really interesting. Should you guard the ship and wait to get rescued while the aliens are growing stronger or should you run out and collect the missing pieces, repair the ship and lift off? It's a tough and compelling decision. Too bad it is mired with all the rules/components fiddleness.

item.name: Antike
item.comment: One of my favorite games. No luck, with very low complexity and multiple winning paths. I like a lot the Rondel mechanic.

item.name: Arkham Horror
item.comment: The theme leaves me cold and there are a few things I would have liked better from functional point of view. It is a good game though, it scales fine to different number of players and seeing that you only use a small fraction of the components I imagine the replayability is quite high. Nightmarish rules, it's one of the few games I always play with the rulebook in hand and every time I discover that I'm doing something wrong.

item.name: Axis & Allies
item.comment: Good introduction to wargames and low complexity dudes-on-map games. Not interested in it anymore. Too much downtime.

item.name: BANG!
item.comment: It was fun at first, now I rarely play it. Can become boring if 2 players are locked in an endless fight and you're not one of them. Or was it because you are one of them?.

item.name: BANG! The Dice Game
item.comment: Surprisingly fun! Way better, not to mention faster than the card game. Love the arrows mechanic on the dice!

item.name: The Battle at Kemble's Cascade
item.comment: Great concept, terrible execution. Extremely fiddly, feels like the first iteration of a cool prototype. A lot of back-paddling involved to correct things that require constant tracking. Avoid

item.name: Battle Cry: 150th Civil War Anniversary Edition
item.comment: I can tell this was the first in the series. Almost immediately want to add house rules to it based off Memoir 44 and Ancients.

item.name: BattleLore
item.comment: I played CC:Ancients. Battlelore is nowhere near that in terms of gameplay. In comparison it looks like a Disney version. Add extremely long setup time and you get a slightly average experience.

item.name: Battlestar Galactica
item.comment:
A little boring for me, not being fan of the series. Ok game and mechanics. I don't see a lot of things going on though for one player. I also don't see the advantage of playing hidden cylon unless you're doing it for the mood of the game.
Update: This game is completely ruined for me after witnessing a game where the cylon player revealed himself from turn 1. All the tension and the paranoia gone, the game was just a boring exercise of skill checks.

item.name: Carcassonne
item.comment: It's nice, light and clean, can be very cutthroat with experienced players...but somehow I just don't like to play it that much.

item.name: The Castles of Burgundy
item.comment: Best Feld game for me. Simple mechanics, not a paralyzing amount of choices and decent scoring complexity.

item.name: Castles of Mad King Ludwig
item.comment: Great fun with this game, similar in style with Suburbia but much better.

item.name: Catan
item.comment: I dislike that half of the game is determined by luck and the other by direct trade. I have no problem with either generally but in this game the experience is always bad for me. I admit it is a nice, clean design though. It's a good game I can't stand to play

item.name: Catan: 5-6 Player Extension
item.comment: This expansion kinda waters down the whole experience. It's good that more people can play the game but I like it even less than the original.

item.name: Cave Troll
item.comment: Boring. Just boring.

item.name: Chrononauts
item.comment:
What a cool concept and what a horrible execution! The game plays by itself, which can be fun for some but for me is not. After winning 3 times in a row because the other players completed my missions for me I decided it's highly unlikely I will ever play this again.
The cards are hilarious indeed but really, how many times can you laugh at the same joke?

item.name: Citadels
item.comment: Nice game. Very high quality artwork, very easy to explain and play, but tends to drag too long with more than 5 players.

item.name: Clash of Cultures
item.comment: First play through was pretty bad. Gameplay is simple, and I like the concept behind it and the theme. However, there are too many effects that the player needs to constantly remember and as the game progresses it only gets worse. As a result the game is taxing on attention and leads to AP. Nail in the coffin, the event cards felt unfairly random.

item.name: Claustrophobia
item.comment: Simple and to the point dungeoncrawler. Don't care too much about the setting and would have liked something more generic and better "hero" customization. Love the mechanics though.

item.name: Codenames
item.comment: I'm not at all into party games but this one is really well made. Love playing as spymaster!

item.name: Combat Commander: Europe
item.comment: I was reluctant first and thought it has too much silly randomness but the more I play it the more I like it. It's one of the best games I own and I believe this level of complexity is as much as I can take. But you never know...

item.name: Commands & Colors: Ancients
item.comment: The best in C&C series. It deserves a 10 even though it has terrible artwork.

item.name: Concordia
item.comment: Awesome game, excellent depth.

item.name: Conflict of Heroes: Awakening the Bear! (second edition)
item.comment: I admit this one get 1-2 extra points because of graphics. The game itself is good but nothing extraordinary. Keeping this mostly for the solo possibilities.

item.name: Conflict of Heroes: Awakening the Bear! – Russia 1941-42
item.comment: Very good wargame and highly accesible. I think it's a bit dry though.

item.name: Core Worlds
item.comment: Waaaaaay too much information on the cards. It works with 2 players but the more you add, the more it bogs down. Would never play this with 4-5 players.

item.name: Cyclades
item.wishlistcomment: Great game. Played it once, have to get it.

item.name: Darkest Night
item.comment: Typical solitaire/coop game, random stuff happens, you react, rinse, repeat. The events are kinda samey and the choices are not all that interesting. You always play 4 heroes so it's essentially a 4 player solitaire

item.name: Darkest Night: With an Inner Light
Dead of Winter: A Crossroads Game
item.comment: Amazing narrative moments in this game! I would give it a 10 but it's a little bit long.

item.name: Defenders of the Realm
item.comment: I really like this. Some of the design elements feel a little bit rough but the whole idea runs excellent. A step up from Pandemic is the fact that heroes have multiple abilities and personal quests. It feels more cooperative because you do have personal choices to make within the group.

item.name: Descent: Journeys in the Dark
item.comment:
Best dungeon crawler I've played. Lots of tactical choices and replayability. Most conflicting rules and unanswered questions also. Great game with a lousy rulebook.
Killed by the second edition.
item.haspartslist:
I have the following monster miniatures available:
Bane spiders: 4 tan, 2 red Skeleton Archers: 2 tan, 2 red Beastmen: 3 tan, 2 red Hellhounds: 1 tan, 1 red Razorwings: 1 tan, 1 red Sorcerors: 1 tan, 1 red Manticore: 1 tan Ogre: 1 tan Golem: 1 tan Ferrox: 1 tan, 1 red Kobolds: 6 tan, 3 red Blood Apes: 2 tan, 1 red Dark Priests: 1 tan, 1 red Deep Elves: 1 tan Trolls: 1 tan

item.name: Descent: Journeys in the Dark (Second Edition)
item.comment: Definitely the best dungeoncrawler, vast improvement over predecessor.

item.name: Descent: The Road to Legend
item.comment:
I wanted very much to like this. The premise is great and the main concept is everything I wanted out of the campagn play. Unfortunately many details have been overlooked and this kills pretty much all the fun. - There are numerous combos from Descent that while performing ok in the base game, are plain broken in RtL. Too many to mention. - To get those combos, which are ridiculously rewarding, the heroes will follow the same strategy every game. Any other path means poor play. Even the latest FAQ admits this, by removing certain skills from the game. - The plots are too easy to complete for the Overlord (except the one that leads into the keep, which of course you HAVE to play to the end). Some Avatars are also too much to deal with when combined with the right plot. - As noted by many others it is fairly easy to raze Tamalir once the first Beast upgrade kicks in, which should happen early in the game. - 3 of the 4 lieutenants are based mainly on beast minions. This leaves little choice on the Overlord's part in strategy if he wants to protect his forces.
Scripted, repetitive and broken in parts. This is all I can think of when I play RtL
Brief reports of my experience so far: first campaign ended during Copper. After 2 failed atempts to engage Alric, both ending in total party kill, we agreed the Overlord cannot be stoped. I hate playing the heroes. There are just too many odds stacked against them and they cannot win against a careful Overlord. One the other hand I don't mind playing the overlord, so I'll just stick to what I do best.
Second campaign ended short after entering gold. I'm starting to think there is no way the heroes can beat the Overlord, except taking on the Avatar itself. But only one story allows them to go that far.
Third campaign ended in copper. The demon prince combined with the Acension plot is unbeatable as it cuts off the keep from the main map so the heroes only chance is to reach 600 XP, which is very hard to do before the Overlord razes 4 cities, mainly because the keep is located right next to two of them.

item.name: Deus
item.comment:
Fantastic game, lots of interesting choices and combinations, even more so for it's simplicity.
The only reason why this is not a 10: everything in the game feels under player control except getting a building that you really really need. Can be frustrating wasting turns fishing for the right card.

item.name: Dixit
item.comment: The only party game I can stand. Barely.

item.name: Dominion
item.comment: Good game I got tired of playing. Everybody, please stop designing deckbuilding games.

item.name: Dungeon Lords
item.comment:
The mark of a fabulous game? When you don't think for a second about VP and winning strategies, but are completely immersed and think the game in thematic terms. How can I get more monsters and traps to defend my dungeons instead of how to make this engine more efficient and get VPs.
The only thing I don't like about it, it doesn't scale well and basically requires you to play with 4 people. But it is well worth it, I love this game.

item.name: Dungeon Lords: Happy Anniversary
item.comment: One of my favourite games, now with upgraded components!

item.name: The Dungeon of D
item.comment: I love good dungeon crawlers. If there's one thing I love more than a dungeon crawler, that's a FREE dungeon crawler.

item.name: Dungeon Petz
item.comment: How can you not like this game? They poop!

item.name: Dungeons & Dragons: Castle Ravenloft Board Game
Dungeons & Dragons: The Legend of Drizzt Board Game
item.comment: Same as the other ones in the series, except Drizzt hero with 2 attacks and ability to strike before monsters activate is plain broken.

item.name: Dungeons & Dragons: Wrath of Ashardalon Board Game
Eldritch Horror
item.comment: So far this is fun. I only played it solitaire and I wouldn't try it with more than 4 players as I suspect downtime and keeping interest focused is an issue.

item.name: Elysium
item.comment:
Splendor on steroids
- the game is entirely driven by set collection. First and foremost I'm scanning the cards looking for the numbers I need, powers and combo building are secondary and in most cases purely incidental - the column mechanic felt gimmicky. Remove it from the game and you lose nothing - game was way too long, with too much downtime
Colour me unimpressed.

item.name: Escape: The Curse of the Temple
item.comment: Real time rolling wears down after a couple of plays but it's still a good game.

item.name: Evo
item.comment: I liked this one, even though I'm not a fan of bidding.

item.name: Field Commander: Alexander
item.comment: A very good solitaire game. I like the combat mechanics very much, they are a nice blend of randomness and player choices.

item.name: Galactic Emperor
item.comment: I love the theme and the game is pretty good. There is something about it though that doesn't seem right. I guess it happens when you copy an existing great game and modify slightly its mechancis. It feels like a watered down version of Puerto Rico.

item.name: Galaxy Trucker
item.wishlistcomment: Love Dungeon Lords, love Sci-Fi, love Vlaada's designs. I still have to play this but it looks like I would enjoy it very much.

item.name: A Game of Thrones: The Card Game
item.comment: Base game is great. The more options you add, the more confusing things are and the less I am inclined to play it. I tried it with about 5-6 added expansions and the setup takes longer than the game itself.

item.name: Gears of War: The Board Game
item.comment: The game is surprisingly good. I'm not a fan of the video game so the theme fells completely flat for me but the gameplay is pretty fun.

item.name: Gravwell: Escape from the 9th Dimension
item.comment: 6 nimmt on steroids. Very fun!

item.name: Hanabi
item.comment: The game is very good, I just grew tired of playing it. Can evolve into a pretty mean experience sometimes, depends on whom you play with.

item.name: Hannibal: Rome vs. Carthage
item.comment: Fantastic game! Best theme, best mechanics, best level of complexity. I will play this any time, anywhere.

item.name: Hyperborea
item.comment:
Very streamlined experience, I love how elegant the system is. The only issue I have so far is downtime. Would probably never play it with more than 4, even that seems like a stretch.
Update: Been soloing this a lot lately, fantastic game!

item.name: Imperial Settlers
item.comment: First play didn't go too well. Far too long and fiddly for my taste. Which is surprising, considering this was supposed to be a streamlined 51st State.

item.name: Intrigue
item.comment: Interesting idea and simple in execution. However not for any crowd.

item.name: Julius Caesar
item.comment: I'm giving this one 1-2 extra points for the theme but it's still a good design. This would be a 10 with a more interesting combat mechanic (see Sekigahara).

item.name: Legendary Encounters: An Alien Deck Building Game
item.wishlistcomment: Waiting for iPad version. Or trade.

item.name: Legends of Andor
item.comment: Decent adventure game, clean design and superb graphics.

item.name: Level 7 [Omega Protocol]
item.comment: LOS and range rules are silly but the rest of the game is pretty good. + very interesting adrenaline and cooldown mechanic + each commando feels unique and plays differently + partially customizable missions makes them highly repayable

item.name: Lords of Waterdeep
item.comment: I have the iOS version so this one doesn't get tabled much anymore. Excellent worker placement game, probably the best for me. Not a fan of the mandatory quests though, although I understand their reason. Used improperly can really wreck the game for some players and let others run away with the win.

item.name: Lost Legends
item.comment: Very swingy game, you never know if things are going to work your way or not. It also seems to suffer from positive feedback loops. People who do well can kill more monsters, get better equipment, gain more money and experience. Those who do poorly stay poor throughout the game, I've rarely seen anybody making comebacks. Still fun to play though, mostly because I'm a sucker for the theme.
item.wishlistcomment: Reading bad things about this one. Must try before buy

item.name: Love Letter
item.comment: Very good game, especially considering it's just a couple of cards.

item.name: Mage Knight Board Game
item.comment: Perfect in every way. Maybe not the PvP but I don't play with that anyway.

item.name: Mage Knight Board Game: The Lost Legion
item.comment: Makes the original an 11. Must have!

item.name: Maquis
item.comment: Fun little PnP. Too random but not bad for what it is.

item.name: Memoir '44
item.comment: 10 years later I still love playing this.
item.wishlistcomment: Not interested in later printings as the thave coloration issues

item.name: Merchants & Marauders
item.wishlistcomment: Interesting game. Not so much of a pirate myself but I could use a pirate game. Has to bea easy to play. Need to read more reviews.

item.name: Mr. Jack
item.comment: Fun game but after a while it gets boring. Maybe more characters help, don't know, didn't feel the need to try.

item.name: Mystery Express
item.comment: Dreadful experience. Takes a lot of time and a lot of writting down stuff so you don't forget what's happening. If you play without taking notes, you either have a really REALLY good memory and attention span or you just don't care what's happening.

item.name: Nations
item.comment: Streamlined Through the Ages. I like the simplicity of it and don't miss the fiddly resource pools. On the other hand, the game feels a bit more random and less tight.

item.name: Pandemic
item.comment: Ok game, simple mechanics, I can see the appeal. Doesn't engage me though and I don't like playing it with other people as it is 100% solitaire puzzle.

item.name: Pandemic Legacy: Season 1
item.comment: Fun experience, recommend every one to give this one a try. Once it's over it's over though, I don't see how you can continue playing it. Maybe the story carries forward in episode 2?

item.name: Pathfinder Adventure Card Game: Rise of the Runelords – Base Set
item.comment: Great mechanic that eventually suffered the same fate as all other similar games: killed by too many inconsistent, wonky and fiddly card interactions.

item.name: Patrol: Lost!
item.comment: Urban warfare variant.

item.name: Pirate's Cove
item.comment: Kids game. Not that there is anything wrong with that...

item.name: Pocket Civ
item.comment: Very good civilization game. Someday I will make a professional version of this.

item.name: Prophecy
item.comment: The best adventure game I played, mainly because it is filled with choices, something you don't get in other adventure games, where you just roll and move and roll some more for combat resolution.

item.name: Puerto Rico
item.comment: Sooooooo good! I can't wait for a high quality aniversary reprint!

item.name: Race for the Galaxy
item.comment: Very good card game with a theme I enjoy a lot. I got tired of playing it after adding the first two expansions. Sometimes, more is just a little bit too much.

item.name: Red7
item.comment: Smart game.

item.name: Robinson Crusoe: Adventures on the Cursed Island
item.comment: Wildly unpredictable, fiddly and chaotic but it delivers a great story.

item.name: Roll for the Galaxy
item.comment:
I like the idea of rolling dice, I like how they are all thematically different. I like how planets give you more dice while developments give you game effects. All good there.
What doesn't work for me is marring all this with the mechanics from Race for the Galaxy. Rolling dice removes or greatly diminishes the amount of control the player has over his strategy when combined with that system. Hence the various ways to mitigate it: reassignment powers, dictate, etc. While they managed to correct that and it is possible to follow a general strategy, it also makes the game extremely fiddly. I would have preferred a streamlined system even if that meant severing the connection to the action selection in Race.

item.name: Roll Through the Ages: The Bronze Age
Runebound (Second Edition)
item.comment: Sold as soon as I played Prophecy.

item.name: Runebound (Third Edition)
item.comment: Decent adventure game. Skills concept is interesting and leads to some interesting choices. Combat is a bit long and fiddly because most of the time the optimal path is visible and then it's just a matter of going through the motions.

item.name: Saboteur
item.comment: Great choice for party game. Very quick to understand and play and very fun with a crowd. It's one of the best gateway games. I hate it. Unfortunately I played my share of this game to last for a lifetime. I recomend it to everybody but refuse to play it.

item.name: Samurai Battles
item.comment:
Fiddly gameplay and systems, even if they are thematic for most part. I find I don't have the patience anymore to flip through the rulebook making sure I'm not omitting minuscule rules.
The miniatures are unwieldy because of the long thin spears and the flag insert in the base. Blocks would actually be preferable. The spears also tend to break easily. Did I mention spending 10 hours putting the damn things together?
The card quality is ridiculously bad, literally on par with printing on your own printer. Flimsy and prone to bending.
Other than that seems to be pretty decent C&C entry.

item.name: Sekigahara: The Unification of Japan
item.comment: Excellent game and slick design. Love the combat mechanic!

item.name: Shadows over Camelot
item.comment: Good game...and with the right group it's a very nice experience. So far everybody I introduced to this game likes it. The traitor idea is brilliant but if he plays open and cutthroat there is no way you can beat him with few loyal knights.

item.name: Shogun
item.comment: I like the theme a lot and have a soft spot for "dudes on map" games. Unfortunately they have in common something that I dislike profoundly in games: downtime. This game is the king of downtime, it takes literary hours between turns. It's fun to watch the action but still, too much for what it is.

item.name: Shogun
item.comment: Overall a nice, clean, design. Not my type though, as much as I love the cube tower.

item.name: Sid Meier's Civilization: The Board Game
item.comment:
The first games were great but I consistently encountered things I don't like to have in games: - Kingmaking - Leader Bashing - The more the game progreses, the more it clogs. - Take-that style of playing the culture cards - Combat system looks smart but it's just as random and basic as dice, except it takes 10 times longer to play.
I wish I liked the game, because it has the perfect theme, but I don't. Traded away.

item.name: Space Alert
item.comment: The best cooperative game I have played. Pure, chaotic fun. Most original design too.

item.name: Space Hulk: Death Angel – The Card Game
Star Realms
item.comment:
I don't get the hype. Must be the price point and the quick play, because the game itself is not that great. Interesting combos but for most part too random to feel rewarding. Prefer Ascension over this, especially on iOS.
Edit: Rating downgraded after winning a game by simply purchasing the most expensive card I could get my hands on each turn. Mindless play = no fun

item.name: Star Wars: Imperial Assault
item.comment: Improved version of Descent/Doom system. Fixes some of the major issues like going after the weakest hero, removes the overlord deck (or at least simplifies it). The scenarios so far seem to be more interesting and tense, the campaign has a good flow to it and I can see a lot of variability and high degree of replayability. Still the same game though, same crazy amount of stuff to track and unclear interactions. Guess you can't have one without the other.

item.name: Star Wars: The Card Game
item.comment: Way too much to track. It works if you're into LCG, for me there is too much unneeded complexity.

item.name: StarCraft: The Board Game
item.comment: I will never play with more than 2 players again. Too much downtime. There are better games for the same time range. Also the amount of micromanagement of this game kills pretty much all the fun. Some mechanics could have been less complicated for what they provide. The combat aspect is nice but the main mechanic of order placement in reverse order is too unforgiving to be enjoyable.

item.name: Talisman (Revised 4th Edition)
item.comment: Boring roll and move adventure.

item.name: Tash-Kalar: Arena of Legends
item.comment: I was expecting more. It's good...I guess? When it's your turn. Matching patterns is appealing to me so that part of the game is fun. Then you might as well walk away from the table and come back in 10 minutes. I fail to see how you can plan for anything until your turn comes back since a single piece removed will force you to rethink the entire play. So really, all you do is play your best combo right now. Which is not all that hard to figure out. Underwhelmed :(

item.name: Tempus
item.comment: This is a great super-light civ game.

item.name: Through the Ages: A Story of Civilization
item.comment: This game is fiddly, long, sometimes unbalanced, has virtually no artwork and a very steep price. In spite of all that, I love it! It delivers the best civilization experience out there.

item.name: Thunderbolt Apache Leader
item.comment: Good game but too fiddly.

item.name: Thunderstone
item.comment:
A step up from Dominion, and not only because this game actually HAS a theme. You get the impression you are actually trying to defeat monsters and level up heroes. Earning VP is a side effect of the game.
The gameplay is wonky though and there are numerous loose ends. I'm sure they are all fixed in FAQ but I don't care enough to bother.

item.name: Ticket to Ride
item.comment: Easy to learn, easy to play, THE gateway game. Excellent game

item.name: Ticket to Ride Map Collection: Volume 1 – Team Asia & Legendary Asia
item.comment: Team Asia - my absolute favourite way to play TtR

item.name: Tide of Iron
item.comment: Good design. Captures most of what should be in a wargame with beautiful packaging. It drops in a middle spot I don't want to fill though. If I want an easy game, I'll play Memoir instead. If I want a meatier game, I'll go for CC:E.

item.name: Tokaido
item.comment: Not my type of game but definitely not bad, I'd play this once every two moths or so. Beautiful artwork.

item.name: Twilight Imperium (Third Edition)
item.comment:
No matter how much I like the theme and how many times I played it, I cannot get past it's problems: - Too long, and when I say that I don't complain about the actual time. I just have the impression that the game is crawling. - No good reason to fight and usually no good outcome either, unless you completely overwhelm your opponent, therefore turtling is a very good strategy. - Stupid Initiative-Imperial combo.
I walk away from the game feeling tired, not satisfied, so that's why I will avoid it in the future.
item.haspartslist: Everything and anything except the plastic miniatures.

item.name: Twilight Imperium (Third Edition): Shattered Empire
item.comment: Great adition to the basic game, and it fixes a couple of problems with the main game. Recommend that you do not play without it.
item.haspartslist: Everything and anything except the plastic miniatures.

item.name: Twilight Struggle
item.comment: Fantastic game

item.name: Walnut Grove
item.comment:
Very impressed with this game, two comments only: - It's brutal. Expect first game to be learning experience and make generous allowance for take-backs - A bit concerned about replayability, even with the random tiles it still seems like you'd be doing basically the same thing every game
Played it again, still impressed with the design.

item.name: War of the Ring (first edition)
item.comment: Good game, but lots of problems with the rules...the main being it takes more to explain than play the game. Nontheless I like it and I play it whenever I have the possibility.

item.name: War of the Ring (second edition)
item.comment: Everything I loved about the first edition, but with better components

item.name: War of the Ring: Battles of the Third Age
Warfighter: The Tactical Special Forces Card Game
item.comment: I have to try this one more often to see if the rating goes up. Love the theme and I've been looking for something like this for a long time. It's not very streamlined though, seems like a lot of things could be simplified without affecting the gameplay.

item.name: Warhammer Quest: The Adventure Card Game
The Witcher Adventure Game
item.comment:
Played the PC game with 3 other AI players and it felt like a frustrating slog. I imagine the boardgame is ten times worse with all the bookkeeping required.
Okay game if you don't mind the "go places, flip cards for random events" type of experience.

item.name: World of Warcraft: The Boardgame
item.comment: Avoid, even if you're a fan of the online game.

item.name: XCOM: The Board Game
item.comment:
I liked the iPad integration a lot. I wish the board game that came with it was better ;)
A couple of examples of weird design choices: - TPK on first roll is almost irrelevant in case of satellites/scientists but game wrecking in case of soldiers/interceptors. Why? - To promote interaction each role has a card that's useful to another role. Except in practice is much better to just hand them the card and let them do it themselves. - One of the missions requires elite soldiers to complete. If you haven't built up to that (and you will not in your first game), it's essentially game over when you almost thought you made it. Sneaking in a nasty surprise in the final round seems to me like a bad call.
And so on. I guess the game falls in line with the typical FFG fare so I'm only half disappointed.

item.name: Zooloretto
item.comment: Interesting mechanic.
